Those who die having betrayed what they hold sacred, embracing their treachery to their core, might return in this broken, gnarled form of snapped bones with a crooked grin. The creature's fingers end in curling claws that hook and hold, and the duplicity in its heart bleeds out to twist allies against one another. Despite the creature's name, anyone can become this manifestation of betrayal.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The crooked man can't abide self-sacrifice and withers in its presence.

monsterFluff.name: Crowstorm

entries: {@i Fiendish Murder}

A crowstorm is a great, swirling mass of dark feathers accompanied constant, harshly malevolent crow calls. Hundreds of fiendish birds fly in unison, their beady eyes dripping blood as they swoop down to tear at the flesh of their victims. A crowstorm's horrific caws mingle into an eerie cacophony of pleading whispers, and it robs the gift of flight from anything that draws too close.

entries.name: Secret
entries: While they might take the form of crows or possess crow bodies, crowstorms are held at bay by drawn images or crafted effigies of crows.

monsterFluff.name: Deepdreck

entries: {@i Poisoned Subterranean Wretch}

Deepdrecks were miners long ago who found themselves far too deep beneath the earth, where they were cursed and corrupted by deforming powers. Now they tunnel and dig greedily, bloated with poisonous gases.
Astute observers have noted that these monsters occasionally bear a resemblance to missing loved ones who have long been thought dead.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The toxic essence of deepdrecks is disrupted by pleasant scents such as flowers, perfume, spices, or incense.

monsterFluff.name: Drakkenhob

entries: {@i Dragon Disguised as a Festival Horse}

The drakkenhob is a draconic monster with a sinister disguise, presenting itself as an actor wearing a horse costume, such as a mounted knight or a festively clad rider. Its draconic head resembles a decorated or armored horse's head, and its sharp teeth fit together to appear like blunt, harmless decorations. The drakkenhob uses this benign guise to get close to its prey, which are typically within crowds near festivals or parades, before it summons its similarly garbed hunting hounds and strikes. Its breath is a blood-curdling wave of terror that makes lesser victims drop dead from fright alone.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Unable to resist revelry and merriment, drakkenhob are driven away by payment offered in gold or alcohol.

monsterFluff.name: Dream Eater

entries: {@i Devourer of Nightmares}

Dream eaters are horrors that feed  on the dreams, sense of identity, and some say the very souls of other creatures. Dream eaters have the bodies and wings of great owls, while their beaks are filled with blunt, humanlike teeth and hide long snaking tongues. Their feathers are drab colors on the exterior, but their wings display a dazzling cascade of rainbow hues on the undersides when unfurled.

These colors flow and shift, mesmerizing the dream eater's prey and leaving them helpless. A creature whose dreams are devoured is left in a listless, near-blank state. Without help, their victims waste away.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Dream eaters are confused by the intricate patterns on moth wings, and it disrupts their own colorful hypnosis.

monsterFluff.name: Ferryman

entries: {@i Cursed Undead Boatman}

Ferrymen are Undead created through the use of curses and jinxcraft and are doomed to ply the waters where they were raised. They pole through the bayous and rivers, and even across land on a wave of swamp water, in coffin boats. They can focus the malice of their curse through the light of their lantern poles, jinxing enemies or those who try to force a ride without payment.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Paying a ferryman 3 copper coins lifts any curse the creature placed on the payer, and it entitles one to a single unnerving but safe ride in the ferryman's coffin boat.

monsterFluff.name: Festerhulk

entries: {@i Fungal Undead Giant}

Festerhulks are dead giants whose corpses are infested with fungus engorged by the magic of decay. This fungus has consumed and replaced much of the giant's flesh and now animates the corpse. The heads of these giants are often completely overtaken by repulsive mushrooms and other fungal growths. The spores given off by their infestation can spread to victims killed by festerhulks, giving rise to further Undead.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Festerhulks shrink from sunlight, which harms the fungus that animates them.

monsterFluff.name: Fleshdobbin

entries: {@i Flesh-Crafted Amalgam of Knight and Horse}

Fleshdobbins are abominations created when a horse and its rider are horrifically melded through fleshcrafting magic. Their limbs stretch and deform, though afterward, their bodies resist further transformation.

Fitted with saddles and bearing savage weaponry, these monsters may look like riderless horses from a distance, but each leg culminates in oddly human- looking gnarled hands with fingers ending in wicked claws. Their voices are the comingled shrieks of human and horse.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Affixing a bridle to a fleshdobbin causes the instincts of the horse within the amalgam to take over, becoming a loyal steed once more.

monsterFluff.name: Gloomwood

entries: {@i Blighted Treant}

Gloomwoods were once treants in service to an archfey, but they were corrupted by a supernatural fungal blight. The growth bores through their trunks and into their souls, making the gloomwoods cruel and vicious, interested only in spreading more decay. Fungal spores drift from their trunks and branches, rotting any flesh and digging into the ground around them to spread the blight.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Carving the Sylvan name of the forest the gloomwood once called home into the creature's trunk quells its aggression.

monsterFluff.name: Gobblegeist

entries: {@i Blood-Drinking Avian Predator}

Gobblegeists are massive birdlike monsters with earth- toned plumage, reptilian faces and claws, and a metallic beak edged with sharp teeth. These ravenous creatures descend from forest canopies or hilltops to snatch their prey unawares and carry them off to feed on their blood in solitude. Their single, unblinking eye can unnerve and dazzle more alert prey, making would-be threats an easy meal.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The folk who venerate the Old Ways believe that a seven-pointed star repels gobblegeists. They keep the monsters at bay by painting or weaving star sigils from wicker to hang from their homes or in trees.

monsterFluff.name: Herald of Fools

entries: {@i Leader of Fiendish Revels}

Heralds of fools lead troupes of fiendish revelers in service to the enigmatic Lord of Fools, a clown or jester entity who is a curious mix of levity and cruelty (though always with a sense of irony). The heralds are agile and graceful, every movement a dance, spinning their banner poles in intricate displays that can swiftly turn from entertainment to death.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Heralds of fools are wonderful dancers, and they must never stop dancing, or they quickly perish.

monsterFluff.name: Hospital Horror

entries: {@i Mutated Experiment}

Hospital horrors were once people, but now they are repulsive mockeries created through surgical  and magical alteration. They have no memory of  their past lives, existing only within a chemically induced rage. Often, they are conditioned by the use of specific command phrases that allow them  to be controlled.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Hospital horrors have spent much of their existence being prodded with needles, so being pierced frays what few wits they retain.

monsterFluff.name: House of Horror

entries: {@i Cursed House Brought to Malevolent Life}

Houses of horror are living houses, often angry or bitter due to the circumstances of their awakening. They were once mundane buildings or dwellings where powerful magics of life and death took place and infused the stones and timber.

Houses of horror jealously covet the true life that its former inhabitants enjoyed, or they carry echoes of the suffering that bodies and souls experienced within them. The houses vent this fury on any who enter, tormenting and terrifying trespassers. The souls of those who die inside are trapped, waiting to be unleashed upon future victims.

entries.name: Secret
entries: While not haunted houses in the traditional sense, houses of horror can have their consciousness quelled by the same exorcism or purification rituals that put unquiet spirits to rest or drive out possessing spirits.

monsterFluff.name: Hypnovulfen

entries: {@i Hungry Hypnotizing Wolf}

Hypnovulfen resemble massive wolves with unnaturally large orange eyes and wide, crooked maws. Despite their size, hypnovulfen are shockingly stealthy, able to stalk their prey and snare them with a hypnotic gaze from the shadows. The gaze beguiles victims into seeing a loved one beckoning them closer for a warm embrace. All the better for a hypnovulfen to feed and consume the unfortunate morsel's memories.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Hypnovulfen have no power to mesmerize anyone holding a keepsake or memento received from a loved one, as it overpowers the false beckoning of the monster's gaze.

monsterFluff.name: Invader Out of Space

entries: {@i Intruder From Beyond the Stars}

Invaders out of space appeared after a falling star blazed down from the cosmos. These alien beings have an unsettling habit of appearing between glances and silently watching. Invaders stand upright like a biped, shrouded in what are either voluminous robes or draping folds of skin.

Observers who are lucky find the invaders gone in a blink, and those who aren't so fortunate hear the bloodcurdling hiss these things from beyond the stars emit as they attack. All that remains of their victims is a spray of gray powder amid crumpled clothing.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The invaders have little resilience to the toxic and virulent threats of the Material Plane, and they succumb quickly to diseases and poisons.

monsterFluff.name: Kackle

entries: {@i Laughing Lantern Bearer}

Those who were particularly sadistic in life and died consumed by wicked mirth linger as Kackles—ghostly figures that drift above the ground, always flitting just out of sight. Adorned in tattered cloaks and concealing hoods or hats, their hollow laughter echoes through dark places, fading in and out to confuse and terrify their victims. Kackles always carry lanterns lit with ghostly flames, the color of which changes to reflect a kackle's current cruelty of choice.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Kackles are bound to their lanterns, and smashing their lights can snuff out the spirits' existence.

monsterFluff.name: Keeper of the Blight

entries: {@i Druid Transformed by Blight}

Keepers of the blight arise from Fey beings that dwell in a natural region that becomes overtaken by a supernatural or spiritual rot. Where they once tended the balance and cycles of their home, keepers are consumed by the blight and channel their magic through fungus, mold, and rot, pushing the cycle of life toward death, decay, and the flourishing of things that thrive in gloom.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The fungus growing throughout keepers of the blight empowers and sustains them, and killing that growth diminishes their power.

monsterFluff.name: Ketgrinn

entries: {@i Voice-Stealing Trickster}

Ketgrinn are catlike Fey spirits who delight in puzzles, riddles, and bargains. They have large, bright eyes and too-wide grins that gleam starkly even in shadows. Ketgrinn are tricksters and spies, often sent by those they serve to steal the voices of a rival's minions to sow chaos and confusion.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Ketgrinn can't resist a puzzle or riddle, and a difficult one can send a ketgrinn's mind spiraling.

monsterFluff.name: Lake Dredger

entries: {@i Undead Aquatic Monster}

Lake dredgers are Undead water behemoths, such as whales, giant fish, or dinosaurs. These creatures are reanimated through the deep, primal fear of the unknown horrors that lurk in the murky depths. They dwell in the beds of lakes, rivers, or oceans, dredging up the detritus to replenish their ever-rotting mass.

They also add to their decaying bulk by feeding on living creatures, especially drawn to those who exhibit fear of the deep. Once prey is devoured, it is impaled on its cracked ribs until the waterlogged flesh becomes one with the beast's.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Lake dredgers exist because of the fear of the unknown, and their essence is undone in the presence of a captured or crafted depiction of themselves, such as a drawing or carving.

monsterFluff.name: Lurker in the Dark

entries: {@i Thing That Goes Bump in the Night}

Lurkers in the dark are wicked Fey creatures who prey upon the fearful, vulnerable, and alone. They resemble nightmarishly distorted people with gray skin, lank hair, and three-fingered, clawed hands. Their limbs move in impossible ways, allowing them to slip through and hide within spaces that seem far too small. They delight in stoking their victim's fears by whispering from spaces a person couldn't fit. When the terror crests, the lurkers strike, drag their victims into the dark, and vanish with them.

entries.name: Secret
entries: {@condition Frightened|XPHB} children know that lurkers in the dark can be held at bay by clutching a beloved stuffed animal.

monsterFluff.name: Maidenwood

entries: {@i Twitch-Warped Ambushing Tree}

Maidenwoods are creatures birthed from tree stumps by old magics, often arising from curses that turn the forest against a transgressor. They scuttle on roots like legs, and the broken trunk becomes a fierce, grinding maw. The maidenwood's tendrils blossom into lifelike figures it uses to lure its prey close.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The curse that maintains a maidenwood unravels if one is offered an apple—an ancient trick used by witches turned against them.

monsterFluff.name: Mutant Nurse

entries: {@i Caregiver Twisted by Mutation}

Mutant nurses resemble the Humanoids they once were, though an alien mutation writhes within their bodies. They serve as caretakers of healing institutions, though they are fully beholden to whoever, or whatever, altered them to their current state. The nurses all wear a white porcelain mask made in the likeness of their original features, which grounds them to their sense of self and prevents them from losing their will fully to the aberrant influence that changed them.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Mutant nurses go berserk if their masks are destroyed or taken from them, or they become unresponsive if there are no other creatures nearby.

monsterFluff.name: Necrolisk

entries: {@i Subterranean Spirit-Devouring Drake}

Necrolisks are subterranean dragons that feed on the essence of spirits. Tunneling through the ground in search of corpses, especially those buried in graveyards and crypts, they defile the graves and feed on the bodies in an effort to stir up restless spirits, which are then snared in the necrolisks' ephemeral saliva and devoured. Creatures of flesh and blood that disturb the dragons might also find themselves as a less preferred, but passable, meal.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Necrolisks are severely allergic to a concoction of lavender, nightshade, and lilies, which causes them to vomit uncontrollably—a boon to anyone swallowed by the monsters.

monsterFluff.name: Night Creature

entries: {@i Bestial Blood Hunter}

Night creatures are fiendish spirits bound into vampire-blood-tainted corpses through profane rituals. The hulking brutes are fanatically loyal to their creators, a fact some vampire overlords learn too late when those they employ to create the night creatures develop ambitions of their own.

entries.name: Secrets
entries: Night creatures are quickly undone by the purity of salt if wiped on a weapon and driven into a wound.

monsterFluff.name: Old Ways Chosen

entries: {@i Devout Follower of Old Gods}

Venerating old and forgotten gods who once held sway over the remote places of the world, the Old Ways chosen keep the last embers of belief and tradition burning. Many of the chosen are insular, keeping to the communities they foster. Some are more open to contact with outsiders, whether to be a beneficent presence or to draw in potential sacrifices to the Old Ways.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Old Ways chosen bind their power into a mask they use as a focus. Without the mask, their magic unravels.

monsterFluff.name: Phantom Hearse

entries: {@i Ghostly Coach of the Dead}
Phantom hearses are ghostly carriages complete with horses and coachmen—amalgamations of tormented souls driven to claim the living and drag them to the land of the dead.

The spirit coachmen strike with phantom whips and weapons, and even fly out to harry foes at a distance, while the ghostly horses drive the hearse in a crushing charge that gathers victims and seals them into a spectral coffin that drains the warmth and vitality from flesh and bone. The tolling bell on the carriage precedes the apparition's appearance, and its sepulchral sound has caused more than a few witnesses to drop dead on the spot.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Phantom hearses are driven to collect the living, and they can't see a living creature that holds its breath.

monsterFluff.name: Pigeon Hag

entries: {@i Vermin Hag of Deception and Control}

Pigeon hags are vain witches who place themselves above every other being. They seek to reinforce that belief by controlling and undermining the knowledge and relationships of others. Pigeon hags often insinuate themselves into a mortal settlement and walk among the people, usually in a position to hear and spread gossip that they can twist and manipulate to their own ends.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The vanity of a pigeon hag is so overwhelming that polishing its ego can leave it flustered and briefly unable to act.

monsterFluff.name: Pumpkin Head

entries: {@i Fiendish Effigy of the Fields}

Pumpkin heads are scarecrows  of straw, sticks, and clothing topped with a carved pumpkin for  a head and animated by a fiendish spirit. They are crafted by demons  to resemble their Humanoid victims and returned to wherever  the unfortunate souls had been snatched from.
These living effigies speak  with the voice of whomever  they replaced, often repeating phrases and behaviors that the missing person said or did in life while stalking and killing new prey.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Pumpkin heads hold a shred of memory from the people they replaced. The sight of a keepsake or memento from a pumpkin head's victim confuses the creature.

monsterFluff.name: Reveler of Song

entries: {@i Fiend of Music and Dance}

Revelers of song are Fiends of music and abandon who turn their art against their foes in destructive reverberation. The revelers dance and play at nearly all times and are known to fly into a murderous rage if their invitations to join the celebration are spurned. A variety of revelers of song exist, depending on the type of instrument a given reveler plays. Drone revelers play the hurdy gurdy and are surrounded by an accompanying swarm of bees. {@item Drum|XPHB} revelers play drums or cymbals, and the world shakes to their beat. Bell revelers play some variety of bell, chime, or gong, and the ringing overtakes all other sounds.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Revelers of song can't accept that any creature is more skilled at an instrument than they are and so can't refuse a musical challenge.

monsterFluff.name: Reveler of Stories

entries: {@i Fiend of Legend and Folklore}

Timeless stories have inspired countless mortals, and the echoes of those stories in the Lower Planes have spawned fiendish embodiments of those tales—the revelers of stories. These Fiends twist the themes of their tales, turning inspiration into doom. The revelers' forms and powers change depending on the theme of stories they embody. Great beast revelers of stories rise from tales of terrible monsters. Hero revelers of stories embody the exploits of knights and other mighty heroes. Witch revelers of stories bring to life tales of wicked witches, wizards, and other magicians.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Revelers of stories exist because of fables, legends, and other tales, and reciting the moral of a story related to the reveler's theme robs the reveler of its potency.

monsterFluff.name: Rotweaver

entries: {@i Fey Thrall of Rot}

Rotweavers were Fey caretakers of the natural world or fey planes who've been corrupted by the power of rot. Rotweavers serve powerful beings of withering and blight as minor acolytes and hunters, working to spread the bounds of their beloved decay.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The rotweavers' fey nature still holds; binding them with iron, such as manacles or a chain, mutes their strength.

monsterFluff.name: Serum Brute

entries: {@i Cursed Giant Enhanced by Alchemy}

Serum brutes are descended from giants who suffered an enduring curse when they failed to take over a Fey domain. They have third eyes, usually in their foreheads, which channel the giants' curse into the world around them. All three of their eyes are sewn or otherwise sealed shut to contain the curse. Serum brutes are further enhanced with—and get their name from—a series of alchemical infusions, often delivered through implanted vessels and tubes, which seek to deaden their sorrow and pain, as well as the disturbing power of their third eyes. They form deep emotional bonds with any who offer them comfort and an escape from the pain of their curse, and they are often willing to die for those allies.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Serum brutes are dependent upon their curse, and magic that breaks curses can leave the giants debilitated and bereft.

monsterFluff.name: Shrouded

entries: {@i Soul Corrupted by the Shroud}

Shrouded are the spirits of the dead—devoid of any ability to reason and corrupted by the deathly mists known as the Shroud. They are raw emotional energy, unfettered and unleashed, manifested into being. The shrouded are constantly whispering about a victim's incompetencies, weakness, foibles, and failings as they engulf their prey to drain the life from them, corrupting their soul.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Shrouded are bound by barriers and lines of iron, which is why cemeteries with iron fences keep them contained.

monsterFluff.name: Skitterswarm

entries: {@i Fetid Fey Centipedes}

Disgusting Fey who delight in warping flesh and spreading sickness can gather into squirming masses of centipedes known as skitterswarms. These swarms lurk in places where foulness accumulates and often serve centipede hags.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Skitterswarms can't resist dead bodies and are drawn to the corpses of Humanoids.

monsterFluff.name: Soulfire Stoker

entries: {@i Engine-Born Spirit of Flame and Death}

Soulfire stokers are Elemental spirits of fire who inhabit furnaces, engines, and boilers that burn bodies or souls. The resulting creature is composed of ghostly flames and steam, with swirling plates of phantom iron that resemble the engine or machine that gave it form. A crackling blend of fire and negative energy, soulfire stokers burn away souls as much as flesh.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Soulfire stokers are compelled to burn corpses they can see, so dead things can bait the spirits.

monsterFluff.name: Squabswarm

entries: {@i Peeping Fey Pigeons}

Fey messengers that take the form of pigeons can gather into flocks, or squabswarms. Hags and other influential Fey use squabswarms as spies and messengers—and sometimes as unerring trackers to locate any who flee responsibility or judgement.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Squabswarms' drive to deliver letters or parcels is overwhelming, and they can be confused by delivery requests.

monsterFluff.name: Vermin Familiar

entries: {@i Infesting Hag Companion}

Capricious Fey spirits incarnated into bodies reminiscent of normal pests, vermin familiars serve spellcasters and especially vermin hags. While they are most often drawn to serve wicked masters, they also delight in playing the part of dutiful servants to corrupt spellcasters who aren't evil.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Vermin familiars are gripped by deep-seated fears shared by the vermin forms they inhabit, and as such, are terrified of dogs and other canines.

monsterFluff.name: Vermin Infestation

entries: {@i Swarm of Verminous Familiars}

A nightmarish amalgamation of centipedes, pigeons, and weasels, vermin infestations are thankfully rare. These swarms of Fey roil and scratch and rend with individual pigeons streaking out to tear at distant foes, becoming a frenzied mass that throws all subtlety and coordination to the wind. At times, the constituent vermin-like Fey seem to be at each other's throats as much as any victims of the swarm.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The Fey spirits that make up a vermin infestation loathe one another and can be tricked into fighting among themselves by a clever suggestion.

monsterFluff.name: Wayward Haint

entries: {@i Lost Soul Bound to Regret}

Wayward haints are restless spirits stuck between the realms of the living and the dead. Be it a curse or an unresolved conflict from their previous life, a haint can't rest until their unfinished business is resolved.

Haints only show hints of who they were in life, taking on a more symbolic form related to the hurt or loss they can't let go of. They tend to repeat their monotonous actions—often imitating those performed in life or reenacting their sorrow—over and over for eternity. When provoked, they can display a volatile temper and lash out with a crushing wave of the grief and indecision that binds their spirit.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Wayward haints can be trapped in empty bottles if they're tricked or forced to pass over one.

monsterFluff.name: Weasel Hag

entries: {@i Hag of Soul Twisting and Terror}

Covetous and bedecked in stolen and gifted teeth, weasel hags are Fey creatures that sow nightmares and temptation to wickedness. They often surround themselves with weasels and boogleswarms, using them as spies, thieves to steal trinkets (especially lost teeth), and to spread their malign influence.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Weasel hags' love of teeth goes beyond a mere quirk. They can't refuse a tooth willingly given by its owner and can't harm the owner for a time.

monsterFluff.name: Wellwyrm

entries: {@i Serpent Lurking Beneath the Surface}

Wellwyrms are serpents originally touched by cruel Fey masters. The wyrms live in shallow waters where land- dwelling creatures frequent, such as wells and watering holes, lying in wait to coil around unsuspecting victims. Wellwyrms then drag their prey into water, or into burrows they dig under seemingly safe ground, to drown or suffocate.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The sound of a hunting horn drives wellwyrms into a panicked frenzy.

monsterFluff.name: Wildpyre

entries: {@i Spectral Blazing Beast}

When animals perish in flames, their escaping spirits can cling to the fire that took their lives and arise as wildpyres. These Undead resemble the kind of animal they were in life, though made of ghostly flames. They lash out at anything in their vicinity, fanning the flames that consumed them.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Water can extinguish the undying flames of wildpyres, despite their ephemeral existence.

monsterFluff.name: Woodwarped

entries: {@i Facsimile Grown of Root and Vine}

Whispered among forest dwellers is the tale of a cursed vine, said to creep into the bodies of the living or the dead, twisting them into woodwarped. These wooden creations of tangled roots and bark take shape into a crude yet eerily familiar imitation of their hosts. Those that slay their hosts are sometimes clad in the stolen clothing and armor of their victims, silently wandering the woods with hollow eyes that reflect the unnatural force that binds them to the forest. Cutting pieces from their bodies is a dangerous proposition, as the fragments quickly grow into new woodwarped.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Woodwarped possess a deep fear of axes—tools capable of severing not only their bodies but their bond to the forest. The mere sight of an axe is enough to hold the creatures at bay, and the bite of its blade slices them like smoke.

monsterFluff.name: Wormhost Surgeon

entries: {@i Parasitical Physician}

Alien parasitic worms that infest the brains of Humanoid bodies mutate their hosts into wormhost surgeons. These aberrant husks are obsessed with anatomical study and with finding new Humanoids to infest with larval worm slurry to propagate their kind. They can pass for ordinary people in most cases but must take care to hide their exposed brains and the wriggling worms within their flesh.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Wormhost surgeons are drawn to seek out and infest sapient victims, so intelligent creatures with veiled minds slip beneath the surgeons' notice.

monsterFluff.name: Corn Dolly

entries: {@i Grain Husk Companion (Curved blade plated in gold)}

Crafted from dried husks and bound with twine, corn dollies' delicate forms are stitched together with rustic care. Their faces are ink-brushed with simple, childlike expressions—smiling mouths that curve a bit too wide and hollow eyes that seem to stare far beyond the physical world. The Constructs are spirits of deceased Humanoids drawn to the hollow corn husk shell, seeking refuge. These spirits retain faint traces of who they once were—a protective instinct entwined with a simmering fury. Once animated, the dolls reflect this dual nature: acting as silent guardians one moment and vengeful specters the next.

monsterFluff.name: Crooked Hare

entries: {@i Crooked Trickster (Anything stolen or gained by trickery)}

Crooked hares look like rabbits at first glance, but their true nature is given away by the antlers and wings they grow and the cunning gleam in their eyes. They are mischievous tricksters that delight in stealing things from unsuspecting travelers and hiding them in amusing, slightly dangerous, or just unlikely places. If roused to anger or cornered, crooked hares deliver a bite that carries an unsettling—if minor—curse. Despite their troublesome nature, crooked hares might serve as companions for woods-crafty folk who have a good sense of humor.

monsterFluff.name: Devil's Glove

entries: {@i Five-Fingered Fungus (Rare wood chips)}

Comprised of five twitching, blood-red tendrils lined with black slime, the devil's glove fungus feeds voraciously off decaying matter, unwary insects, and small creatures. Resembling a long-fingered hand, they grow from bulbous roots that look like leathery, white eggs and constantly emit an overpowering scent of death and rot. Despite their unpleasant aura, these fungus creatures can form beneficial relationships with others, providing nourishment and resilience in exchange for protection and a ready supply of decaying material to feed upon.

monsterFluff.name: Dingpot

entries: {@i Jovial Cauldron Helper (Spices and rose quartz)}

Dingpots are animated objects created to assist in magical and alchemical research—or simply to help in the kitchen. Often cheerful, dingpots delight in serving up delicious meals, soothing tea, and the occasional magical draught.

monsterFluff.name: Ghost Crawler

entries: {@i Spirit Spider (Silk threads soaked in wine)}

Silent and nearly {@condition invisible}, ghost crawlers skitter between the darkest corners, hiding and watching. Their diminutive, ghostly, spider-like bodies are ill-defined and as translucent as a wisp of smoke, while their legs are long, uneven, and jarringly solid. The webs they spin are ephemeral and ghastly, allowing the crawlers to sense through them regardless of the distance.

monsterFluff.name: Goatstealer

entries: {@i Hungry Livestock Snatcher (Incense and spoiled meat)}

The hairless, reeking goatstealers are vicious predators and scavengers that earn their name from their habit of preying upon livestock. They latch onto prey with wicked, needle-like teeth, delivering lethal venom and devouring creatures far larger than its wiry frame would suggest is possible. Especially dangerous in packs, the carrion-yet-peaty stench of goatstealers is the stuff of legend.

monsterFluff.name: Hemonculus

entries: {@i Sanguine Servitor (Fresh blood and gem dust)}

Hemonculus are servitors created by a blood magic ritual that binds a fiendish spirit into a blood-formed body. For the cost of a small sacrifice in blood (the creator's own or otherwise), the creatures serve as spies and assist in procuring further blood for magical use.

monsterFluff.name: Magpie of Omens

entries: {@i Bird of Fate and Fortune (Crystal or gemstone shards)}

To those who respect the Old Ways, this bird of black and white brings tidings both fair and foul. Although the omens the magpie delivers can bring joy and grief in equal measure, they are always trustworthy.

monsterFluff.name: Moonshine

entries: {@i Lingering Soul Guide (Broken glass and powdered onyx)}

When a person dies with unfinished business, their soul can remain shackled to the living world as an Undead spirit. Usually such spirits rest and move on when their business is concluded, but some remain as companions, guides, and helpers for the living. Moonshines are spirits who resolved their emotional tethers but have chosen to linger on. They often take a liking to a living person and choose to help them through their life's journey.

monsterFluff.name: Nameless Thing

entries: {@i Unknowable Lifeform from Beyond (Meteorite fragments)}

Nameless things are alien minds bound into physical vessels, most often diminutive animals, objects, or pieces of monsters. These creatures can creep into the world when outer influence seeps into existence but are usually deliberately invited.

monsterFluff.name: Ravencraft

entries: {@i Undead Avian Amalgamation (Silver wire)}

Ravencrafts are a grotesque fusion of feathers, sinew, and bone. Their tiny form is a contorted and twisted nightmare carelessly sewn together into the mockery of a bird. The mere presence of a ravencraft is an affront to natural death and can keep further death at bay, or they can chill the hearts of their foes with cries of torment from beyond the grave.

monsterFluff.name: Salmon of Knowledge

entries: {@i Elemental Font of Wisdom (Crushed opal)}

Legends speak of the salmon of knowledge—shimmering fish said to embody the wisdom of the ages. Their scales gleam with an iridescent light, and they are forever enveloped in a sphere of gently flowing water that defies gravity. This magical orb is said to carry the essence of the sacred Current of Wisdom—where knowledge of all time and space flows through the rivers of the cosmos.

monsterFluff.name: Witchwoven

entries: {@i Helper Made of Twine and Twigs (Ruby wrapped in a wicker cage)}

Witchwoven are little dolls or effigies made of sticks, twine, and other simple materials, then imbued with life. Some happen naturally in places suffused with old nature magic, but most are created to serve as familiars by spellcasters knowledgeable in the Old Ways.

monsterFluff.name: The Barrow King

entries: {@i Undying Monarch of the Damned}

The Barrow King is known only by the armies of Undead he commands, which all slumber in tombs and burial mounds. Wights and their zombie conscripts arise when trespassers violate the resting place of the king's army, and tales speak of a tide of death that will sweep across the world if the king himself should awaken. Records of the king's living exploits and identity are near nonexistent, but rumors abound, and the storm of stories and myths may conceal grains of truth.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The Barrow King's only true weakness is his name, written in the runic form of his lost native language. A weapon inscribed with his runic name becomes his bane.

entries.name: Barrow King's Lair
entries: The Barrow King's lair is his burial mound and the surrounding region of resting places for his vast army.

monsterFluff.name: The Beast of Blight

entries: {@i Manifestation of Rot and Decay}

The Beast of Blight was once known as Farryn of the Greenwood, a druidic protector of the natural cycle who delved into forbidden lore to save her dead lover. Her love was virtuous, but in the end, it caused nothing but pain. Rot overtook the druid, and she is now a monstrous being that spreads and thrives on decay. The Beast of Blight moves effortlessly through decay and spews putrid spores when roused to anger.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Buried deep within the Beast of Blight, a tiny fragment of Farryn still exists. If shown an image of her lost love, the ignited memory will burn away the rot.

entries.name: Beast of Blight's Lair
entries: The Beast of Blight's lair is a cave in the heart of a rottenforest where blight creeps endlessly forth.

monsterFluff.name: The Brimstone Behemoth

entries: {@i Apocalyptic Colossus of Hellfire}

The emergence of the Brimstone Behemoth means armageddon for whatever realm it erupts into. A Fiend as old as time itself, it is made of hellfire, brimstone, and dying worlds. It has a malevolent will that seeks only to bring about mass extinction and apocalypse. The only hope for many civilizations has been through the regular willing sacrifice of citizens to slow or delay the inevitable doom to come.

entries.name: Secret
entries: If a soul willingly perishes in flame or lava to ensure the behemoth's demise, the Fiend will find its flame quenched.

entries.name: Brimstone Behemoth's Lair
entries: The Brimstone Behemoth's lair is a vast underground cavern filled with magma, flames, and smoke. Once this colossus awakens, the crater that its cavern becomes serves as its lair.

monsterFluff.name: The Chained Reaper

entries: {@i Burdened Harbinger of Death}

The Chained Reaper is all that remains of a once-noble orc caretaker of the departed called Yorgrim. Having been corrupted by the mists of death known as the Shroud, the Chained Reaper is a being of hatred and bitterness, striving to cremate all living things in its balefire before binding them in chains of anguish.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The Chained Reaper carries a memorial stone upon its back. If one can read aloud the names inscribed there, their purity will burn away the reaper's fury.

entries.name: Chained Reaper's Lair
entries: The Chained Reaper's lair is a mausoleum holding its own empty grave and those of its former companions.

monsterFluff.name: The Crimson Abbot

entries: {@i Unholy Crusader of Blood}

In life, the Crimson Abbot was a virtuous crusader named Sir Marius Renathyr but was seduced by the sweet whispers of an archdevil of deceit and pride who masqueraded as a goddess of righteousness. On the brink of death, the abbot accepted the whispered offer for eternal life, and in so doing, was transformed into a creature of unbearable pride with an unquenchable thirst for blood. He continues to work in the name of his â€œgoddessâ€ and has gathered a fanatically loyal congregation eager for his promise of pure, everlasting life.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The Crimson Abbot's pride is nearly unshakable, but seeing a true reminder of the righteous man he once was can crack his faÃ§ade.

entries.name: Crimson Abbot's Lair
entries: The Crimson Abbot's lair is a blood-soaked monastery where unworthy mortals are burned in sacrifice, and vampire minions study truths hidden in blood.

monsterFluff.name: The Dusk Mother

entries: {@i Shade of Motherly Anguish}

The keening wail of a mother is unmistakable and haunting, and the legends that tell of the Dusk Mother barely scratch the surface of her terrifying existence. She carries a pair of oversized shears and a great bell she tolls to accompany her wailing. Her eternal torment stems from her children, who met their fate due to the Dusk Mother's negligenceâ€”or perhaps her wrath. Now she cries in shame for that loss as she searches for her children, or for souls to claim and fashion into dolls in a futile attempt to fill the void in her doomed soul.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The Dusk Mother's only true weakness or fear is the remnants of her childrenâ€”some trinket or toy they played with in life or, more chillingly, their spirits, which also wander the world, but never in the same place as their mother's shade.

entries.name: Dusk Mother's Lair
entries: The Dusk Mother's lair is a home or other place in a settlement where tragedy struck, most often those involving children or families broken by loss.

monsterFluff.name: The Galloping Headsman

entries: {@i Headless Executioner of Vengeance}

The Galloping Headsman is a formidable combination of human and horse musculature fused with nightmarish magic and dark revenge. Gouts of flame burst from where its head and tail should be and dance dangerously along the edge of its massive two-headed axe. A burning, skull-shaped pumpkin floats eerily in one hand, its fiery visage a constantly shifting train of agonized faces.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The Galloping Headsman's original skull is its greatest weakness, and anyone holding the skull becomes the apparition's bane.

entries.name: Galloping Headsman's Lair
entries: The Galloping Headsman's lair is the stretch of road that serves as the anchor point of the creature's search for vengeance.

monsterFluff.name: The Ghostlight Locomotive

entries: {@i Corrupted Ghost Train}

The Ghostlight Locomotive is the engine of a phantom train that travels unseen between the realms of life and death, ferrying souls of the dead to their afterlife. During its normal operation, the locomotive burns doomed spirits for fuel and races along spectral, misty rails that appear as it travels, and it has little awareness beyond its crucial task.

Only a drastic event, such as the corruption of its soul-made fuel source, can turn the Ghostlight Locomotive from its endless duty, whereupon it stokes a consciousness of the innumerable souls it has burned and vents the fury of the damned upon any obstacles in its path. When pressed, the residue of wicked souls left from the burning of its corrupted fuel overwhelms the engine's amoral nature, driving it to malevolent and hateful destruction.

entries.name: Ghostlight Locomotive's Lair
entries: The Ghostlight Locomotive's lair is a 1-mile-radius Emanation of shrouding mist originating from the locomotive. This mist doesn't extend within the cars of the {@i Ghostight Express} that the locomotive pulls.

monsterFluff.name: The Grinning Sinner

entries: {@i Dealer of Jinxes}

Once the dashing pirate captain Briggsy Kratch, the crocodile-folk now known as the Grinning Sinner made a bargain for power with a spirit known as Snake Eye Jack. The sinner grew discontent with the power he was gifted and tricked Jack into a coffin before sealing him inside. Now the Grinning Sinner siphons his trapped patron's cursed power and makes bargains of his own to snare the souls of the desperate and foolish.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The Grinning Sinner holds his prowess and reputation as a fearsome and successful pirate captain above all; causing him to doubt his renown can turn his hexed magic against him.

entries.name: Grinning Sinner's Lair
entries: The Grinning Sinner's lair is the derelict riverboat casino, the {@i Dead Man's Hand}.

monsterFluff.name: The Harvest Terror

entries: {@i Demon of Secrets and Despair}

Once a jovial soul imbued into the body of a scarecrow called Ol' Jericho Sticks, the Harvest Terror is now a nightmarish abomination. It is a mockery of demonic flesh molded in the shape of a crow-like scarecrow. Its twisted body is made of molding wicker with four tattered, blackfeathered wings sprouting from its back. An oversized corvid head with amber eyes sits upon its broad shoulders, its dark beak a jagged mess, and it wields a chipped, wicked scythe covered in old blood. Forever hungry, the Harvest Terror feeds on secrets and those that keep them.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The soul of Ol' Jericho Sticks still exists in the dark recesses of the Harvest Terror's mind. Singing or playing Jericho's favorite song tips the balance of control over Jericho's stolen body.

entries.name: Harvest Terror's Lair
entries: The Harvest Terror's lair is the extraplanar corn mazeknown as the Fields of the Crow.

monsterFluff.name: The Horned King

entries: {@i Sin Made Manifest}

Every sinful, selfish action in the world pours a fraction of itself into the Horned King, a being composed of every mortal who has surrendered to temptation. Fortunately, under normal circumstances, the Horned King exists as an ephemeral spirit with no physical presence. During times of upheaval, when a great many mortals give in to their selfish desires or when another powerâ€”such as a deity, demon lord, or archfeyâ€” interferes, the Horned King is made manifest, and with it comes the weight of sin flooding back into the world that created it.

entries.name: Horned King's Lair
entries: The Horned King's lair is the forest clearing where a twisted tree focuses the malevolent will that gave rise to the king's physical presence.

monsterFluff.name: The Jinxed Leviathan

entries: {@i Curse-Wrought Swamp Monster}

Once a normal alligator that dwelled in a cursed swamp, the Jinxed Leviathan was warped by the strange hexes and twisted spells of nefarious magicians who sought to defeat the deathly spirit known as Snake Eye Jack. Growing to colossal proportions and infusing with the essence of misfortune itself, the Monstrosity could not be controlled and devoured its makers. Now, it lurks in the still, black water of hexed bayous, always seeking its next meal, upon which it unleashes its jinxcraft before feasting.

entries.name: Secret
entries: An idol of the fabled deal maker Snake Eye Jack that has been blessed by one of Jack's followers can turn the Jinxed Leviathan's own cursed power against it.

entries.name: Jinxed Leviathan's Lair
entries: The Jinxed Leviathan's lair is a cursed swamp steeped in confounding magic.

monsterFluff.name: The Lord of Fools

entries: {@i Fiendish Master of Revels}

The Lord of Fools is the embodiment of revelry, cherishing amusement at any cost. He most often leads a procession of revelers of song, revelers of stories, and heralds of fools, compelling townsfolk and travelers to join their celebration to the exclusion of all other concerns. Many of these celebrants dance, drink, and make merry until they drop—sometimes dead! The Lord of Fools laughs all the louder and longer at their demise.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The Lord of Fools thrives on laughter and amusement, so when someone doesn't react accordingly to one of his japes, he becomes enraged at that creature to the exclusion of others.

entries.name: Lord of Fools' Lair
entries: The Lord of Fools' lair is the Fool's Revel carnival.

monsterFluff.name: The Tall Man

entries: {@i Murderous Archfey of the Dark Wood}

The Tall Man is a mysterious entity that haunts an accursed forest. Once, he was an archfey who ruled a now-forgotten court, renowned for its dances that lasted for nights on end. Doomed now to walk his rotting forest, the Tall Man finds pleasure where he can by tempting travelers and forest denizens alike to play hide and seek with him—with deadly results.

entries.name: Secret
entries: Dancing forgotten steps once performed in the fey court that the Tall Man formerly ruled shreds his being.

entries.name: Tall Man's Lair
entries: The Tall Man's lair is the dark forest he now haunts, where his forgotten Fey court once thrived.

monsterFluff.name: The Vermintoll Abomination

entries: {@i Verminous Coven Amalgamation}

The magic that binds hag covens together is far more powerful than many spellcasters can fully comprehend. Vermintoll abominations come about when the magics of a centipede hag, a pigeon hag, and a weasel hag enmesh and fuse the witches into one mass, bound to their cauldron.

entries.name: Vermintoll Abomination's Lair
entries: The Vermintoll Abomination's lair is a decrepit hideaway, often hidden in plain sight such as an attic, basement, or a seized home.

monsterFluff.name: The Weeping Widow

entries: {@i Matron of Malevolent Medicine}

Once a priestess committed to healing the sick through divine rites, the Weeping Widow abandoned the gods after a personal tragedy and turned to sinister science. Believing she knows how to best treat the suffering and make them stronger, she employs a harrowing regimen of alchemical and medical experimentation to wipe minds and alter bodies, whether the patient wants the treatment or not.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The only way to force the Weeping Widow to live up to her moniker is to remind her of the family she lost, such as her husband's sword or portrait, which forces her to confront what she has become.

entries.name: Weeping Widow's Lair
entries: The Weeping Widow's lair is the sanitorium where she conducts her horrific experiments.

monsterFluff.name: The White Worm

entries: {@i Eldritch Devourer of Memories}

Born of a forgotten realm beyond the stars, the White Worm is an eldritch horror resembling a humungous, pallid grub that ravenously hungers for memory. Greedily consuming the memories of any beings capable of remembering, its mere existence sends out shockwaves of alien psychic energy. It also serves as the queen of a hivemind colony of infinite wormlike spawn that seek mortal hosts to feast upon and control.

entries.name: Secret
entries: A specific series of constellations and star paths through the heavens is a deadly poison to the White Worm if it consumes that memory.

entries.name: White Worm's Lair
entries: The White Worm's lair is a secluded lake and the shores surrounding it.

monsterFluff.name: The Wicker Man

entries: {@i Blazing Sacrificial Colossus}

The ultimate expression of a cult's dedication to its patron is the Wicker Man. This massive Construct is woven from wicker and bound with wire and iron bands in the shape of a great bipedal effigy. The chest cavity and limbs are hollow where sacrifices can be secured, with the wicker skin forming cage-like bars and gaps. Celebrated and protected with a cult's very existence, the Wicker Man stands silent and impassive until it is ignited while filled with living sacrifices. Then it comes to life and seeks to consume any nonbelievers—and sometimes even the faithful.

entries.name: Wicker Man's Lair
entries: The Wicker Man's lair is the hilltop where it is constructed and venerated.

monsterFluff.name: The Wild Titan

entries: {@i Ferocious Giant of the Wilderness}

Wandering the most inhospitable mountain ranges, the Wild Titan is the wilderness made manifest, created long ago by a forgotten will for a purpose that none know. Favoring solitude in the most remote places of the world, when it encounters settlements and "civilized" people, it wants only to turn them to primal savagery or crush them beneath its immense bulk.

entries.name: Secret
entries: The name of the Wild Titan's forgotten creator is its undoing. Recovering the lost name and carving its glyph form into a stone creates a zone that severs the titan's connection to the wild.

entries.name: Wild Titan's Lair
entries: The Wild Titan's lair is a hollowed- out peak in the mountain range the creature stalks.

legendaryGroup.name: The Barrow King
regionalEffects: The region containing the Barrow King's lair is changed by his presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Empire of Desecration
entries: A {@spell Hallow|XPHB} spell cast within 1 mile of the lair fails, but any resources used to cast it aren't wasted.

items.name: Necrotic Shroud
entries: When a living creature within 1 mile of the lair regains {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} as part of finishing a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, it can only regain up to half its {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} maximum.

regionalEffects: If the Barrow King dies or moves his lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Beast of Blight
regionalEffects: The region containing the Beast of Blight's lair ischanged by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Fouling Blight
entries: Within 6 miles of the lair, ability checks made to forage for food or water have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}, and magic that creates food or water only produces half the normal amount.

items.name: Rapid Decay
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, objects that aren't worn or carried have {@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB} to Necrotic damage, and the length of time in which a dead creature can be brought back to life is halved.

regionalEffects: If the Beast of Blight dies or moves its lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Brimstone Behemoth
regionalEffects: The region containing the Brimstone Behemoth's lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Relentless Blaze
entries: Within 10 miles of the lair, flames become driven to spread and consume. Every hour, contained fires in that area have a {@chance 10} chance of spreading to a flammable object within 10 feet. Uncontained fires spread out of control in 10 minutes.

items.name: Tenacious Lava
entries: A creature that takes damage from lava within 1 mile of the lair starts {@hazard burning|XPHB}, and it takes {@damage 1d6} Fire damage instead of {@dice 1d4} when it burns.

regionalEffects: If the Brimstone Behemoth dies or moves its lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Chained Reaper
regionalEffects: The region containing the Chained Reaper's lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Chained Vitality
entries: A creature that isn't a Construct or Undead that finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} within 1 mile of the lair must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or have its {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} maximum reduced by 5 (to a minimum of 1 HP).

items.name: Falling Shroud
entries: Thin mist arises within 1 mile of the lair. Undead with the Incorporeal Movement trait in that area have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) checks.

regionalEffects: If the Chained Reaper dies or moves its lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Crimson Abbot
regionalEffects: The region containing the Crimson Abbot's lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Fresh Blood
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, spilled blood  doesn't dry out or coagulate, instead remaining fresh for 24 hours.

items.name: Incinerate Heresy
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, when an enemy of the abbot's takes Fire damage, that creature starts {@hazard burning|XPHB} until the end of its next turn.

regionalEffects: If the Crimson Abbot dies or moves his lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Dusk Mother
regionalEffects: The region containing the Dusk Mother's lair is changed by her presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Enduring Dirge
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, creatures with an Intelligence score higher than 4 who can speak at least one language absently sing nursery rhymes or funeral songs without intending to.

items.name: Thoughts of Loss
entries: Whenever a living creature within 1 mile of the lair finishes a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, it must succeed on a DC 15 Charisma saving throw or it gains no benefit from the rest.

regionalEffects: If the Dusk Mother dies or moves her lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Galloping Headsman
regionalEffects: The region containing the Galloping Headsman's lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Encroaching Doom
entries: Within 6 miles of the lair, an air of doom clings to creatures. Creatures have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on saving throws made to avoid or end the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition that aren't caused by the Galloping Headsman.

items.name: Interminable Journey
entries: Paths warp and stretch within 6 miles of the lair. In that area, travel pace outside of combat is halved.

regionalEffects: If the Galloping Headsman dies or moves its lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Ghostlight Locomotive
regionalEffects: The region containing the Ghostlight Locomotive's lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Ghastly Shroud
entries: When a creature that isn't Undead finishes a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} within 1 mile of the locomotive, the creature must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or any time it regains {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, it only regains half the amount. This effect ends when the creature next finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} or receives a {@spell Lesser Restoration|XPHB} spell or similar magic.

items.name: Spirit Calling
entries: Within 1 mile of the locomotive, {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} {@creature Shrouded|CrookedMoon24} and {@creature Specter|XMM|Specters} are abundant and drawn to any creature that attacks the Ghostlight
Locomotive or that tries to keep pace with, climb, or enter the {@i Ghostlight Express}.

regionalEffects: If the Ghostlight Locomotive dies, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Grinning Sinner
regionalEffects: The region containing the Grinning Sinner's lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Fate's Wheel
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, if the number rolled on a die to restore {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} is even, increase the number rolled by 1. If the number rolled is odd, reduce it by 1.

items.name: Run of Bad Luck
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, a creature that rolls a 1 on a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB} must subtract {@dice 1d4} from its next {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}.

regionalEffects: If the Grinning Sinner dies or moves his lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Harvest Terror
regionalEffects: The region containing the Harvest Terror's lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Amber Eyes
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, amber-eyed crows watch everything. Enemies of the Harvest Terror have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) checks in the region.

items.name: Spilled Secrets
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, creatures other than the Harvest Terror have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}) checks made to keep secrets.

regionalEffects: If the Harvest Terror dies or moves its lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Horned King
regionalEffects: The region containing the Horned King's lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Sweet Temptation
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, a creature that acts on a sinful impulse to the detriment of a {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} or {@variantrule Indifferent [Attitude]|XPHB|Indifferent} creature increases its {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} maximum and current {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} by 10 until it finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. Creatures are aware of this effect. This can't occur again until the creature finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

items.name: Tenacious Curses
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, saving throws against curses have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}.

regionalEffects: If the Horned King dies or moves its lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Jinxed Leviathan
regionalEffects: The region containing the Jinxed Leviathan's lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Hanging Hex
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, when a creature other than the Jinxed Leviathan rolls a 1 or a 20 on a {@variantrule {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}|XPHB}, the next {@variantrule {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}|XPHB} the creature makes has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}, and it can't have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}.

items.name: Murky Waters
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, swamp water is cloudy and shows fleeting faces in the murk. Creatures in the water have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) checks.

regionalEffects: If the Jinxed Leviathan dies or moves its lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Lord of Fools
regionalEffects: The region containing the Lord of Fools' lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Empty Treats
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, carnival snack food is abundant even in unlikely places. The food is delicious but offers no sustenance. A creature that eats the food can't feel the effects of starvation (though they still suffer the effects) for 24 hours.

items.name: Pratfalls
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, ability checks or saving throws made to avoid the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}.

regionalEffects: If the Lord of Fools dies or moves his lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Tall Man
regionalEffects: The region containing the Tall Man's lair is changed by his presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Deepening Shadows
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, shadows stretch far beyond what they should. Creatures can find a sufficiently shadowy spot to hide in, even without cover, 50 percent of the time.

items.name: Too Quiet
entries: Sounds are muffled within 1 mile of the lair, halving the distance at which sounds can be heard.

regionalEffects: If the Tall Man dies or moves his lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Vermintoll Abomination
regionalEffects: The region containing the Vermintoll Abomination's lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Endless Vermin
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, Giant Centipedes, Giant Weasels, and pigeons (use the Raven stat block) are common nuisances. They steal Tiny objects and befoul food.

items.name: Loyal Dwelling
entries: The lair itself, including any greater structure or complex it resides within, rejects intruders. Ability checks to pick locks or find secret doors have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}.

regionalEffects: If the Vermintoll Abomination dies or moves its lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Weeping Widow
regionalEffects: The region containing the Weeping Widow's lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Dulled Memories
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, creatures have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Intelligence checks made to recall information related to painful or emotional memories.

items.name: Faded Dreams
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, creatures who sleep or Trance have only vague impressions of dreams and recall no details.

regionalEffects: If the Weeping Widow dies or moves her lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The White Worm
regionalEffects: The region containing the White Worm's lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Alien Growth
entries: Strange life grows rampant within 1 mile of the lair. In that region, {@creature Grick|XMM|}, {@creature Purple Worm|XMM|}, and {@creature Wormhost Surgeon|CrookedMoon24|Wormhost Surgeons} are common.

items.name: Psychic Phantoms
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, creatures are plagued by horrid nightmares. When a creature sleeps or enters a Trance and finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} in that area, it must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or gain no benefit from finishing the rest.

regionalEffects: If the White Worm dies or moves its lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Wicker Man
regionalEffects: The region containing the Wicker Man's lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Biting Flames
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, when Fire damage is dealt to a creature outside the Wicker Man's dedicated cult that has {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} or {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Fire damage, the creature takes an extra {@damage 1d6} Necrotic damage.

items.name: Endless Praise
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, cultists of the Wicker Man who sing their cult's praises or hymns can be heard up to 300 feet away, even through a {@spell Silence|XPHB} spell.

regionalEffects: If the Wicker Man dies or moves its lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: The Wild Titan
regionalEffects: The region containing the Wild Titan's lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Whiteout
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, there is a {@chance 75} chance every day of heavy precipitation.

items.name: Wild Hunger
entries: Within 1 mile of the lair, creatures always feel ravenously hungry, no matter how much they've eaten. A creature that finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} in this area must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or gain 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level. A creature that doesn't require food succeeds automatically.

regionalEffects: If the Wild Titan dies or moves its lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

spell.name: Ancestral Communion
entries: You invoke the wisdom of your ancestors to gain insight into your trials. When you cast the spell, and at the start of each of your turns for the duration, you gain {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB} if you don't already have it.

spell.name: Blood Bolt
entries: You hurl a twisting bolt of blood at a creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d6} Necrotic damage, and you gain a number of {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Cantrip Upgrade
entries: The damage increases by {@dice 1d6} when you reach levels 5 ({@dice 2d6}), 11 ({@dice 3d6}), and 17 ({@dice 4d6}).

spell.name: Blood Sacrifice

components.m: a drop of your own blood

entries: You sacrifice a portion of your life force to enhance your magical power. When you cast this spell, you take {@damage 1d6} Necrotic damage, which can't be reduced or prevented in any way. For the duration, when you cast a spell that deals damage, one target of the spell (your choice) takes an extra {@damage 1d6} damage of the same type as the spell's normal damage type (your choice if there are multiple).

entriesHigherLevel.name: Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot
entries: The damage you take and the extra damage your spells deal both increase by {@dice 1d6} for each spell slot level above 2.

spell.name: Buried Alive
entries: You send your enemies to their graves even if they aren't dead yet. A creature that you can see within range that is standing on the ground must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the ground opens and swallows the target, burying it up to 10 feet deep. While buried, the target has {@variantrule Cover|XPHB|Total Cover}, has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} and {@condition Blinded|XPHB} conditions, and can't breathe. On a successful save, the target has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition, and its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is 0 until the end of its next turn. A buried creature can dig out of the grave by using its action to make a DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check. On a success, it digs 5 feet closer to the surface. If it succeeds by 5 or more, it reaches the surface. When the creature reaches the surface, it exits the ground with the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.
The target automatically succeeds on its saving throw if it's standing on any thickness of stone or metal, or at least 2 inches of wood.

spell.name: Call of the Wild

components.m: a bit of animal fur or hide

entries: You unleash a primal howl that calls lesser creatures to your command. Each Beast in a 100-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from you when you cast the spell must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a target has the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition, it can understand your commands, and it follows them on its next turn to the best of its ability. On your subsequent turns, you can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to issue a new command. On a successful save, a target has the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition until the start of your next turn, but you have no additional ability to command it. The howl is audible within 300 feet.

spell.name: Captivate Undead
entries: You usurp the negative energy animating an Undead creature that you can see within range, attempting to take control of it. The target must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, for the duration, the target has the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition (ignoring any {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to that condition), and it is {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} toward you. On a successful save, the target has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on the next attack roll it makes against you before the start of your next turn. If you or any of your allies damage the target or force it to make a saving throw, the spell ends.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot
entries: You can target one additional creature for each spell slot level above 1.

spell.name: Chorus of the Lost
entries: You summon the eerie song and wailing of lost souls from a point you can see within range. Each creature in a 15-foot-radius {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere} centered there must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 2d6} Psychic damage, and it has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition for the duration. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage, and it has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn. A {@condition Frightened|XPHB} target repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the spell on itself on a success.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot
entries: The damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each spell slot level above 2.

spell.name: Chain of Conviction
entries: You hurl a spectral, barbed chain at a creature that you can see within range. The target makes a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 2d6} Force damage, is pulled up to 30 feet toward you, and is bound by the chain. While bound by the chain, the creature is tethered to you and can't move or teleport to a space more than 30 feet away from you, and you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on attack rolls made against the creature.

On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage only. The bound target repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the spell on itself on a success. If you are ever more than 30 feet away from the target, the spell ends.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot
entries: The damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each spell slot level above 2.

spell.name: Consuming Pyre
entries: You cause a creature that you can see within range to burst into consuming, relentless flames. The target must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 2d8} Fire damage and {@damage 2d8} Necrotic or Radiant damage (choose when you cast the spell), and the radiant flames linger. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage only.

While the flames linger, the creature takes the damage again at the start of each of its turns. The target, or another creature within reach of the target, can take an action to allow the target to repeat the saving throw, ending the spell on a success.
A creature killed by the damage from this spell is reduced to ash, along with any nonmagical equipment it is wearing or carrying.

spell.name: Creeping Rot
entries: You send tendrils of black and gray rot toward a target that you can see within range. Three tendrils then leap from that target to as many as three other targets of your choice, each of which must be within 30 feet of the first target. A target can be a creature or a nonmagical plant that isn't a creature, such as a tree or shrub. In either case, each can be targeted by only one of the tendrils.

A target that is a creature must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it takes {@damage 3d8} Necrotic damage and has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for the duration. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage only. A creature {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} in this way takes {@damage 1d8} Necrotic damage at the start of each of its turns. A {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} creature repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the spell on itself on a success.
A Plant creature automatically fails the initial save, and a nonmagical plant that isn't a creature simply withers and dies.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot
entries: One additional tendril leaps from the first target to another target for each spell slot level above 3.

spell.name: Crimson Harvest
entries: A wave of blood sweeps out from you in a 15-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation}. Each creature of your choice in the wave must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 3d10} Necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

If you damage at least one Small or larger creature, one creature of your choice that you can see within the {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} regains a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to half the damage roll.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot
entries: The damage increases by {@dice 1d10} for each spell slot level above 3.

spell.name: Crooked Ward
entries: You touch an immobile surface and mark a symbol that causes agony in twisted creatures. An {@condition Invisible|XPHB}, 30-foot- radius {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere} springs out from the point you touch. Each Aberration, Fey, Fiend, Monstrosity, or Undead in the {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere} has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on ability checks and attack rolls. When an affected creature enters the {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere} for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or have the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the start of its next turn.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot
entries: You can maintain {@status Concentration|XPHB} on this spell for longer if you cast it using a spell slot of level 4 (up to 1 hour) or 5 (up to 8 hours). If you use a level 6+ spell slot, the spell doesn't require {@status Concentration|XPHB}, and the duration becomes 24 hours.

spell.name: Culling Sickle
entries: You create a ghostly sickle that lasts for the duration and can strike out at your foes. The sickle appears hovering in your space and moves with you. When you cast this spell and as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} on each of your turns, you can direct it to fly at and strike a creature within 30 feet of you. Make a ranged spell attack. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 2d8} Necrotic damage, and you gain {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to half the damage dealt. After the sickle hits or misses, it returns to hover in your space.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot
entries: The damage increases by {@dice 1d8} for each spell slot level above 3.

spell.name: Cursed Cacophany
entries: You focus on a creature that you are familiar with that is on the same plane of existence as you. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be cursed for the duration. Once a target fails its saving throw against this spell, you can't target it with a ritual casting of the spell for 24 hours.

While cursed, the target hears haunting, discordant music and has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests}. The first time the target fails a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB} during a turn, it repeats the save against this spell with neither {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} nor {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}, ending the spell early on a success.

spell.name: Devil's Due

time.condition: which you take when another creature within range takes damage

entries: You absorb a measure of a creature's suffering and escaping vital essence. Expend and roll one {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} Die. You regain a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the number rolled plus your spellcasting ability modifier.
If the creature took damage from a {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB}, double the number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} you regain.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot
entries: You can expend one additional {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} Die for each spell slot level above 1.

spell.name: Dissolution
entries: You touch a creature or nonmagical object and break the target's substance down into its most fundamental components. Make a melee spell attack. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d8} Force damage, and its AC is reduced by 1 against the next attack roll made against it before the end of your next turn.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Cantrip Upgrade
entries: The damage increases by {@dice 1d8} when you reach levels 5 ({@dice 2d8}), 11 ({@dice 3d8}), and 17 ({@dice 4d8}).

spell.name: Eye Burn

time.condition: which you take when a creature you can see within range targets you with an attack

entries: You sting the eyes of a creature attacking you. The target must make a Constitution saving throw (a creature with {@sense Blindsight|XPHB} or {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to the {@condition Blinded|XPHB} condition succeeds automatically). On a failed save, the target has the {@condition Blinded|XPHB} condition until the end of the turn. On a successful save, it must subtract {@dice 1d4} from the triggering attack roll. The target automatically succeeds on its saves against your subsequent casting of this spell for 24 hours.

spell.name: Field of Reaping

components.m: a dried corn husk or wheat hull

entries: You create a shadowy field that reaps escaping life force in a 30-foot {@variantrule Cube [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cube} originating from a point within range. A creature {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} to you in the field when it appears, or when it enters the field for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there, is cursed until the end of its next turn. While cursed, the first time the creature takes damage during a turn, it takes an extra {@damage 1d6} Necrotic damage, and a creature of your choice within the field that isn't cursed by it regains a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the Necrotic damage taken.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot
entries: The damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each spell slot level above 5.

spell.name: Ghastly Charge
entries: You call forth the spirits of long-dead knights, which charge forward from you in a 90-foot long, 20-foot wide {@variantrule Line [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Line}, and then vanish. Each creature of your choice in the {@variantrule Line [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Line} must make a Wisdom saving throw.
